comments.commentBody:

PS: Rangers Mgr. is history by end of next week.

sorry without Boston, Angles, Yankees or Philadelpha in it... I don't feel like we had the World Series this year...  lost interest when the big boys went down... yeah the teams played very well and last nights game was one for the history books, but I hope next year we get real.. Giants vs Yankees..... Yeah Baby!!!!!

If my beloved Bo Sox couldn't win it a very good team did. Cardinals are amazing. Texas did have power hitters but my goodness the errors, flubbed infield balls, hit batters oh my how many of those as the runs kept piling up because of it.

MOST importantly George Bush/Perry eat your hearts out! I am THRILLED the Cardinals won but even more glad the team of Bush tanked. There is a metaphor there somewhere don't you think?
And there it is...SF won last year, however...
Eat your heart out NEW YANKEES! you will never win another world's title HA! HA!
never mind all that -- after the red sox blew it, and then detroit, thank god thank god twas st louis and not texas that took the penant this year

When you hit the corner, low and outside...................well, some nights you get nothing.

As a from-birth Cardinal fan and for years a south Texan, I couldn't win and I couldn't lose. A good series with some unforgettable moments.

I have no psych training, but am an MD, so have more familiarity than most with psych diagnoses. What you describe is not bipolar disorder, but rather sociopathy. Bipolar sufferers swing between extreme mood states and may be suicidal when in their depressive state, but they don't typically plot to inflict serious harm on others. Furthermore, bipolar sufferers don't manipulate their behavior based on environment (ie, behave one way in public and other way in private). Both of those traits ARE typical of sociopaths.

I'm also surprised that the psychiatrists you've consulted have not taken your concerns more seriously: What you describe in no way sounds like normal childhood acting out. And trained child psychs should realize that a child with sociopathic tendencies might well exhibit such contradictory traits in different settings. Perhaps it's your son's young age that precludes them from associating the behaviors you describe with a serious personality disorder. Perhaps you need to consult with a different type of specialist.

Finally, your post immediately brought to mind the movie The Bad Seed, which I happened to see again only recently. I would not claim that the movie represents a completely realistic clinical picture -- it's simplistic and melodramatic -- but it nonetheless has some psychiatric validity: A person who has no sense of right and wrong, who is adept at manipulating others and who creates a persona that seems not only normal but even sweet and charming. This is the definition of a sociopath. The movie is extreme in that in portrays these behaviors in so young a child.

Diagnosis at a distance is fraught with peril, even when made by those with good credentials, which I do not have. So I reiterate the suggestion that you seek out a child psychiatrist with experience in this area. At the very least, perhaps such a clinician can offer a new take on your son's condition.

In the Hurricane Irene makeup, this team showed that they could, on their day, easily handle LA. Clearly they have it in them; now we need only to see it executed. Failure at home and Backe can book his return to Sweden.

It is easy to see what the problem is if you look at what a Tram driver earns in Greece. He is paid through the government by their taxpayers and gets $100,000 per annum and when he retires he gets 80% of this as a pension. The Greek government must borrow the money to pay the Tram Driver.
With tax evasion and high paying government jobs it is simple to see the problem and doesnt have much to do with these trillions and banks everyone is talking about. The trillions is a result not a cause of the problem.

I was sure that Antigua was in the Atlantic, but thought there might be another in the Pacific.  Finally figured the monument abbr had to be nat'l, and got MHP.  Then sat and tried to discover some meaning hidden in "antigun"  (still thinking island I guess).  Wasn't until reading the Blog that I had my "Doh" moment.  Good Friday puzzle.

I hate to admit that there were over 4000 solvers cleverer than I, but I don't
think the clue on Saturday ".....of this weeks grids, read in order..." is a description
of the solution. "in order" , as I interpret it, means one right after another, not
skip from one position on the first grid, then to the same position on the next, etc.
Except for that, I agree that Mr. Berry's concept and execution were brilliant.
The blank grid looked formidable, but the puzzle capitulated quickly. Thanks, Tim, for a clever romp on a Friday.

Daniel, nice demonstration: x=2/x. Can you give a bibliographical reference for it?

The reason I'm asking for it is that I'm not totally convinced. It's an infinite series. The demonstration merely shows that the n-th term is equal to the n+1-th term divided by 2. And this we know is true both for an infinite series of identical terms all sqrt(2) and also for an infinite series of terms oscillating between 2 and 1. But the fact that x=2/x is valid for both infinite series does not imply the two series are identical.

Hi BWM,

For a full explanation of the answers and the interviews with Patrick Berry and Will Shortz, read "Inside Patrick Berry's Brain: A Review of the "'Crossing' Words Contest" right here.
Okay so for those of us who did all the puzzles but didn't get the answer how about an explanation?

As a student who expects to enter college next year, and as a person who has endured and recovered from chronic depression, I believe I have some familiarity with this subject; I can at least attempt to convey aspects of my own experience. It is impossibly frustrating to explain, however. Doing so requires that other people consider things that threaten their understanding, or should I say their certainty, of how people interact with reality. This topic represents the ultimate in qualified and subjective uncertainties, in describing it I can only believe that there are constants of perception that people can relate to.

As a child, I can now recall that I truly did possess a chronically depressed personality, which first revealed itself mostly as cynicism, but became more clear later. What I learned for the most part however, at least for myself, is that there was little to be done that could effectively relieve this inherent flaw, especially that of a child, that approached the efficacy of medication. It is painful that the rapidity of this treatment is not possible in more cases. Though it did the trick for me, the implications of what this experience means continue to haunt me, and it has left me with knowledge of myself that can be difficult to bear.

Early on I thought Obama the most divisive president in history. I now
find him to be one of the most corrupt. He has committed impeachable
offenses, but no one has the courage to bring this weapon against him to bear.
Given the full court press by the uncouth (sp)Republicans I could care less how President Obama get contributions.

Frankly, Mr. Lichtblau after the GOP mutinous conduct, who gives a rats postier. To keep this country from being ushered into a psuedo-feudalistic rulership his backers efforts are admireable if not heroic.

A writer's misfocus is as a magician's misdirection. Don't you agree tricky Eric?

To prove his political purity, Obama should not take any money from lobbyists, business executives, or anyone connected with Wall Street or a bank. Of course, money from unions or anyone belonging to a union is also tainted if it goes to a Democrat. Obama should only accept donations of $10 or less from people who are not affiliated with any of the above categories. Oh, but no donations from retired people are acceptable, because that might poison objective Presidential decision-making on Social Security and Medicare.
Republicans, on the other hand, are free not only to grab millions of dollars from special interests, but are also free to then give those interests all kinds of tax breaks, regulatory breaks, and special favors, at huge cost to taxpayers' wallets and health - because... they're Republicans.
Maybe the NYT should run a few stories on how the GOP passes legislation that's actually written for them by ALEC, a conservative business group, in exchange for their campaign contributions. Or is it -- It's OK If You're A Republican? (IOKIYAR)

Voting for Obama is to approve his behavior and to approve the system that is so patently corrupt and plutocratic.
Voting for whatever Republican does the same.
It is time to dismantle this system that was established by an all-white, elite male Constitutional Convention, and have a Real, democratic Constitutional convention in which Women, American Indians, Africans from Africa, the US and other skaver nations in the Caribbean and Latin America, immigrants from all the Americas, and Asian ancestry can participate in a way that expresses the collective desires that are now being heard for the first time in the Occupy Movement.
This is probably how and why pharmaceutical companies manage to get laws requiring drugs to be taken by various populations, including children and pregnant mothers, buried in legislation!!!!!

Thank the Supreme Court for unlimited money in campaigns.  The problem is to get elected a candidate has to go where the money is and these days it isn't with ordinary folks.  Campaigns are entirely too long and expensive.  Obama would be a fool to try fight the system as it is in regard to lobbyists.  Feingold and McCain tried some tepid campaign reform but Roberts, Scalia and company shot that down.  Yes, our system is corrupt and in the last 2010 election corporations outspent unions by 4-1 and in my home state alone both the Chamber of Commerce as well as a single corporation outspent the 70,000 members of the Teachers' Union.  So what, exactly, is the point of this article?  Other than to paint Obama with a brush that you could use to color almost every candidate for high offices in this country.  And, yes, there is an unequal treatment of Obama by the media but what's new about that?  Who owns most of the media now?  Is it a real independent and objective source of information anymore?  Not very much of it and the Republican Party wants badly to get rid of PBS.  Why is that, duh?
Great reporting on an important subject.  This is exactly what is needed for the electorate to distinguish between the candidates.  Vote "YES" for continuing our free press!

Barack Obama has millions in re-election dirty money from lobbyists; it's another broken promise.  We all know that Obama's a big spender on the campaign trail then he fleeces U.S., taxpayers, every time he opens his mouth advocating passage of special interest legislation. I'm glad that the Repubs aren't going along with him on his spending sprees. I have to live frugally so I'm voting my purse this presidential election cycle. The pols just don't get a frugal lifestyle!
